newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Isuzu Philippine unit plans expansion.
newsitem.headline: Isuzu Philippine unit plans expansion.

text.p: Isuzu Philippines Corp (IPC), an affiliate of Japan's Isuzu, unveiled on Thursday its business plans to carve a niche in the commercial vehicle market in the Philippines.
IPC President Morikazu Watanabe said the company projects to sell 2,100 units of Isuzu vehicles in the last six months of this year; 9,800 units next year; and 18,600 units in the year 2000.

Isuzu started production in July this year. It currently employs 200 persons in its new headquarters at the Laguna Technopark, south of Manila. It envisions employment to reach 800 by the year 2000, the company said.

"We plan to establish respectable presence in the Philippine automotive scene with a vehicle mix that caters to Filipino motorists' need for reliable, durable, fuel-efficient and technologically advanced pick-ups, off-road vehicles, trucks and buses," said IPC President Morikazu Watanabe.
Isuzu's line-up include the luxurious off-road Trooper, two to four-ton trucks and buses.
Japan's Isuzu and Mitsubishi Corp each own a 35 percent interest in IPC. The other shareholders are Ayala Corp and Rizal Commercial Banking Corp with 15 percent equity each.
Their investment so far in the project amounts to one billion pesos, the company said.
